title: Opinion: Ryan Tannehill is Titans' best choice at QB after Marcus Mariota's benching
text:
CLOSE Tennessee Titans react to their 16 to 0 loss against the Denver Broncos at Empower Field at Mile High in Denver, Colo. George Walker, Nashville Tennessean

DENVER – You had to feel a bit for Marcus Mariota as he stood at a podium, sport coat buttoned, ever dignified, as always accepting all the blame while being peppered with questions for which he didn’t have answers.

Ones like: Do you have any idea if you're still going to be the Titans' No. 1 quarterback?

“I don't,” Mariota replied. "I don't have an idea."

The season felt lost for the Titans on Sunday, buried in offensive ineffectiveness that doesn't appear to have an easy fix. Maybe Mariota was the biggest problem. Maybe he wasn't. But he wasn't the solution.

It's time for the Titans to see what Ryan Tannehill can do as their full-time starter. If he's not the choice for Sunday's game against the Los Angeles Chargers, he should be.

NFL Week 6 winners, losers: Cowboys at a crossroads while Chiefs searching for answers

Awful as things looked Sunday, this season is still salvageable at 2-4. The Titans’ defense is playing well enough to win. It wouldn’t take a juggernaut offense. It’ll just take a capable one.

The Titans can do capable. They’ve done it before. Tannehill has done capable before.

So has Mariota, but now feels different. The move to bench him on Sunday, given the uncertainty of his future with the organization, shouldn’t be taken lightly. It was a weighty step, perhaps signaling the end of a Titans era, even if in this case it was made more out of desperation than sincere deliberation.

Mike Vrabel didn’t have much of a choice. It was past time. That’s how poorly Sunday's shutout loss had devolved for Mariota and a lifeless Titans’ offense. The decision was obvious. By that point, Tannehill couldn’t have possibly been any worse.

And he wasn’t.

It’s good to have a player like Tannehill in these situations. He’s a six-year NFL starter, far better and more proven than an average NFL backup. A case could be made that Tannehill was the Titans’ best quarterback upon first being acquired.

And now the Titans owe it to their defense, if no one else, to see what Tannehill can do in a more extended audition.

Things can change fast in the NFL, and four of the Titans' next five games are at home. Of three opponents to visit Nissan Stadium before the Titans’ bye week, the Chargers (2-4) and Buccaneers (2-4) look beatable, and the Chiefs (4-2) no longer look unbeatable after back-to-back home losses to AFC South opponents.

If the Titans can just find a way to crank the volume up on their offense, their defense is good enough to keep them in any game.

Will Mariota get chances to redeem himself? Probably. At some point.

But in franchise terms, the Titans showed their cards by pulling him. There's no going back. Everything changes now.

You don’t know, at any level, how easily a slumping quarterback can come back confidence-wise after being benched. In this case, you’ve also got long-term ramifications for an entire team to digest. It becomes far-fetched for anyone to believe the Titans truly view Mariota as a preferable long-term quarterback when they don’t even know if he’s the best option next weekend against the Chargers.

Tannehill, at 31 years old, also seems unlikely as a long-term choice. But he’s the best choice right now.

If you know Mariota isn’t going to be around, why not remove the mystery about Tannehill? Why not see what he can do while healthy and somewhere other than Miami?

The Titans don’t need a hero necessarily. They need solid quarterbacking.

And much better pass protection.

And more production at receiver. And tight end.

On second thought, good luck, Ryan Tannehill. Hope you brought your cape.
description: The Titans owe it to their defense, if no one else, to see what Ryan Tannehill can do in a more extended audition after Marcus Mariota's benching.
